author: Callum McGillivray
title: Holt heading to Helensville
text:
Last updated 16:21, February 17 2017 SUPPLIED 
Hayley Holt is running for the Helensville seat. 
Hoping to carve out a new career in politics, Hayley Holt is putting her hand up for the Helensville seat formerly held by John Key. 
The Green Party candidate confirmed her selection to stand for the seat held by the former prime minister today and said her main focus will be addressing the environmental issues in the north-west. 
"We've got to protect our forests, and clean up our waterways," she said. 
Holt says running against Key did not factor into her thinking for running in Helensville. 
The 35-year-old said climate change is not being taken seriously and is of major concern to her and is ultimately what inspired her to stand. 
Holt has identified transport as an issue that "absolutely" needs addressing â€“ particular the need for a train service to and from the area. 
"At the moment the train only goes out to Ranui - It doesn't go any further and it needs to." TV3/SUPPLIED 
Hayley Holt was a judge for New Zealand's Dancing with the Stars. 
The former professional snowboarder and current TV presenter said she has a special association with Helensville. 
"To me, it represents the best of New Zealand and its proximity to Auckland. If I could ever buy a house, which is probably not likely, I would love to have a lifestyle block in Helensville." 
Holt says running against former prime minister Key was not something she was aiming to do, "it was just a coincidence he was the MP for Helensville". 
"John Key didn't actually come into my thinking, which would surprise people." Ad Feedback 
Holt is holding a campaign meeting with Green Party supremos on February 19 to plan her campaign building up towards the general election day on September 23. 
"It's early days, but for the next few months, I will be travelling around the area and talking to people to see what is their main concern." 
When asked if she would be attending events in the area such as the Helensville A&P Show, and Kumeu Show, Holt said "A&P shows of course, that's really important to the area". 
"I'm basically going to everything I possibly can." 
In the 2014 general election the Helensville electorate voted in Key with 22,720 votes (65.17 per cent); followed by the Green Party's Kennedy Graham with 4433 (12.72 per cent). 
Holt has been a co-host of the political debate show Back Benches alongside Wallace Chapman since May, 2016 and is well-known for hosting sports show The Crowd Goes Wild. 
She started ballroom dancing at the age of seven, and appeared on Dancing With the Stars for three seasons, becoming a judge in the sixth series in 2015. 
Holt also won the TV show Treasure Island: Pirates of the Pacific in 2007, and participated in the charity boxing event Fight for Life, in 2011, in which she beat surfer Paige Hareb.
